image.altText: A woman walks in a cat walk in the NIFA's

items.synopsis: Growing up far from the glitz and glamour of the fashion world, Lillardia Briggs-Houston never thought she'd be on a national stage because, while the world is taking notice of Australia's oldest design traditions, big barriers remain.

title.children: Lillardia was 'scoffed at' for wanting to be a fashion designer. Now she's among Australia's best

image.altText: A shirtless man sits in front of a destroyed house with two dogs

items.synopsis: There's been an outpouring of support from the tight-knit rural community on Darwin's outskirts after Les Ferguson lost nearly everything he owns in the blaze.

title.children: Les lost everything but his dogs and his car in a bushfire. Police believe it was deliberately lit

image.altText: Two brown cows stare at camera in cattle pen on ship

items.synopsis: Malaysia has become the second country to suspend live imports from Australia, following Indonesia's claims that Australian livestock have arrived in its ports with the disease.

title.children: Malaysia suspends import of live cattle from Australia citing lumpy skin disease concerns

image.altText: Four NT solar farms including ENI's Bachelor development are sitting idle

items.synopsis: The architect of the NT government's renewable energy road map says the jurisdiction is at risk of missing its 2030 target due to "unrealistic" regulation.

title.children: NT solar investment will 'fall flat on its face', government renewables expert warns

image.altText: An illustration of a SARS-CoV-2 virus particle showing the protruding spike proteins on the virus's surface.

items.synopsis: A COVID-19 variant nicknamed "Eris" — after the Greek goddess of chaos, strife and discord — has been in the news after spreading overseas. But the variant has actually been in Australia for four months.

title.children: The 'goddess of chaos' COVID variant is making headlines, but it’s been lurking quietly for months

image.altText: Filipino marines standing on the deck of a rusty ship.

items.synopsis: For decades the Philippines has stationed a small contingent of marines on a rusting World War II warship that was deliberately run aground on a submerged reef in the South China Sea.

title.children: Why is China so keen to stop resupply ships reaching a dilapidated warship stuck on a South China Sea reef?

image.altText: A street sign reads Bean Street, with a police car on the road and police officer standing in front.

items.synopsis: Police were called to the Rockhampton address this morning, where two bodies were found.

title.children: Two bodies found in Rockhampton home, police declare crime scene

image.altText: A computer screen showing a TPG add

items.synopsis: Hundreds of thousands of Australians face an extra cost to access emails after one of the country's largest internet providers announced plans to close down its in-house email service.

title.children: TPG Telecom to close down free email service, with thousands forced to pay extra cost

image.altText: A close shot of Mr Butler's face, looking serious.

items.synopsis: The opposition will no longer attempt to unwind the government's scheme to halve the cost of hundreds of medications, asking instead for the government to take its act of "good faith" as a chance to redesign the scheme.

title.children: Coalition withdraws attempt to unwind half-price medication scheme, asking for government to delay

image.altText: drone image of shrubs shaped like a lizard

items.synopsis: An eco-cultural effort in southern WA depicting giant Indigenous totems of native animals is helping bring the landscape back to life.

title.children: Giant Aboriginal artworks years in the making sprout across WA

subjects.title: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Art

image.altText: A composite of a boy and a taped-off sinkhole.

items.synopsis: Geologists say "potentially lots" of old goldmine shafts around a town in Victoria could be in danger of caving in due to heavy rainfall last year, but "we have no idea where they are".

title.children: Oliver fell into a sinkhole outside his school. Now there's fears more old goldmine shafts could open up

image.altText: Eight people in colonial-era garb on a longboat at sea.

items.synopsis: Riding horses for three days to get to a dance in the city, chasing kangaroos and jumping fences. An 1800s sketchbook reveals the unlikely life of a colonial woman.

title.children: A type of image you rarely see': Sketches show 'honest' portrayal of colonial life for women

image.altText: Exterior of the Royal Darwin Hospital's emergency and trauma centre.

items.synopsis: A "code yellow" has been declared for the Royal Darwin and Palmerston Hospitals due to "a peak in hospital demand".

title.children: Fourth 'code yellow' called this year for Royal Darwin and Palmerston hospitals

image.altText: A man holds a navy blue flag with white writing, standing behind police tape

items.synopsis: FBI agents shot the Utah man, who referred to himself as a "MAGA Trumper" and had posted online about plans to "clean the dust off the m24 sniper rifle", just hours before the US president was due to land in the state.

title.children: FBI shoots and kills man accused of threatening Joe Biden

image.altText: An oil painting of Kevin Rudd in his Queensland home, a cat wanders on the table in front of him, a wall of books behind him.

items.synopsis: Kevin Rudd is now a permanent presence within the halls of Parliament House, with his official portrait joining those of other former PMs 10 years after he quit parliament.

title.children: Kevin Rudd re-enters parliament — as a painting

image.altText: A composite of an older man with white hair, and tradies standing outside a resort gate.

items.synopsis: The ABC understands about 150 workers at the Sunshine Coast redevelopment site were sent termination letters on Tuesday night, and minutes later, many were sent emails offering re-employment.

title.children: 'Storm in a tea cup': Clive Palmer says resort revamp on track as locked-out tradies line up to collect tools

image.altText: A barge at a port

items.synopsis: The British government says it's trying to "stop the boats", but one of its solutions — a giant, grey barge designed to house 500 asylum seekers — is proving controversial.

title.children: There's a floating 'recipe for disaster' off England's coast — it has links to Australia

image.altText: A female child star with a bob haircut, looks side-on to a camera with a vacant expression

items.synopsis: Lil Tay, whose real name is Claire Hope, made a name for herself by posting controversial but viral videos that involved a lot of profanity as well as designer clothes and luxury cars.

title.children: Child star Lil Tay, famed for controversial online videos, reportedly dies aged 14

image.altText: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un fires a gun in a shooting range.

items.synopsis: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un has dismissed the military's top general, called for a increased weapons production and an expansion of military drills, according to state media.

title.children: North Korea's Kim Jong Un dismisses top general, calls for war preparations

image.altText: A woman stands in front of microphones

items.synopsis: WA's health minister defends moving the state's new maternity hospital almost 20 kilometres away from its current location, as documents reveal issues with the initial plan.

title.children: WA's new $1.8b maternity hospital plan under scrutiny as business case released

image.altText: Anthony Albanese walking on a red dirt road surrounded by people in body paint carrying red flags

items.synopsis: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander agencies, Voice to Parliament advocates and the prime minister have described a conspiracy theory on the length of the Uluru Statement from the Heart as a misinformation campaign to avoid debating the facts.

title.children: Voice to Parliament conspiracy theory an attempt to create 'misinformation and division'

image.altText: A man in an Akubra stands pouring out a bucket of feed to black cows and calves in a dry paddock.

items.synopsis: Just three years since the 'worst drought in living memory' ended, the scars are fresh as dry conditions return to the Hunter Valley with farmers saying it's tougher this time around with higher interest rates and falling livestock prices.

title.children: Hunter Valley cattle farmers consider destocking as drought settles in

image.altText: Margot Robbie in a scene from Barbie, and Cillian Murphy in a scene from Oppenheimer.

items.synopsis: A volatile reporting season continues as AGL loses $1.2 billion while QBE Insurance and AMP record multi-million-dollar profits. Follow live.

title.children: AGL loses $1.2b despite rising power prices, households splurge on Barbenheimer despite fall in spending

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A day after the Commonwealth Bank's record $10.2 billion profit result, we can provide a more considered take on how it stacks up. Unusually, the bank was somewhat at pains to talk down its profitability, pointing out that a return on equity of 14% was well below peaks closer to 20% around a decade ago. And Barrenjoey's very experienced banking analyst Jon Mott believes that could fall even further to 12% as the bank faces cost pressures from inflation, a declining net interest margin and growing loan losses as bad debts rise. He has an $85 price target on CBA shares, about 18% below its current share price of $103.77. "CBA remains in a solid position with a strong management team, dominant share in retail banking and a growing business banking presence. However, the macro and competitive environments are challenging," he wrote. "We believe that the risk/return outlook is skewed to the downside." One of the big risks is how many of CBA's mortgage customers will be able to keep paying their home loans if interest rates go higher, or even remain at current levels. CBA's CEO Matt Comyn told Kirsten Aiken on The Business that the bank has already called about 100,000 customers it considered financially at risk to ask them if they needed any assistance. Hundreds of thousands of CBA customers are rolling off cheap fixed rate loans over the next year or so, going from rates around 2% to variable rates above 6%. And, even for those who aren't in "mortgage prison" and can refinance, it turns out that it's harder to get a cheap deal. As Stephanie Chalmers explains, below, banks (especially the big four) are dialing back aggressive cash back offers and rate discounts for new customers as they seek to maintain their net interest margins and profitability.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Barrenjoey reckons CBA is overpriced above $100 a share

featuredLink.title: Why the honeymoon is over — banks pull back on fight for new borrowers

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The benchmark ASX 200 index of our 200 largest listed companies is +0.05% at 1230pm AEST, up +3.5 points to 7,341.3 points. There's a fair bit of movement... Particularly with a -6.3% slide for shares in Downer EDI and a 3.9% slump for shares in AGL, both of which reported poor financial results today.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX 200 flat after morning trade, Downer EDI and AGL fall

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Some less than stellar news for your household budgets if you have Disney+ in your streaming repertoire — its subscription fees are about to go up. Disney CEO Bob Iger was discussing the entertainment giant's quarterly results overnight, and announced that it would be hiking the price of its ad-free tier of the Disney+ streaming service by 27% — taking it to $US13.99 a month for those in the US. The price increase will take effect in the US from October 12, and the company is planning to roll out the higher subscription payments to its European customers from December. Meanwhile Disney is also going to introduce lower-cost, ad-supported streaming plans to Canada, the UK and other European markets from November 1 at a lower price point. Cracking down on password sharin g is also firmly in Disney's sights, with Iger saying it plans to roll out a strategy similar to what Netflix recently unveiled "sometime in 2024". Right now, Disney hasn't said whether the price increase will affect those of us here in Australia — but given the increases we've seen with other streaming services like Netflix and Spotify, it seems to be a matter of when it affects us, not if .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Disney+ subscription fees to rise in US and Europe

image.altText: Police crouch over evidence behind crime scene tape.

items.synopsis: Detectives have identified a woman whose remains were located at a unit complex in Brisbane last year. The body of Tanya Lee Glover was found tightly wrapped, covered in bedding and hidden behind a brick wall.

title.children: 'Concerning and peculiar': Police yet to determine who killed Tanya and stashed her body at Brisbane unit complex

image.altText: A man with grey hair and dark glasses stands on a street outside a large house and speaks into microphones labelled 7 and 10.

items.synopsis: Today's latest news, as it happened.

title.children: Anthony Albanese will hold talks with US president in October — Catch up with the Loop

image.altText: People walk through the front door of a house, past a For Lease sign.

items.synopsis: About 30 per cent of Australians live in rental accommodation with growing numbers in seats that helped secure government for Labor. But the Greens want to win those votes and next week's National Cabinet will offer clues as to how determined Labor is to stop them, writes David Speers.

title.children: Next week is looming as an important moment for Australian housing

image.altText: A black and white photo of an unseen woman holding up a hand to protect herself.

items.synopsis: Victims of sexual assault who go to trial in NSW are still being accused of lying in 95 per cent of cases, making the experience harrowing and contributing to ongoing rape myths and stereotypes, a report finds.

title.children: 95pc of sexual assault victims in NSW accused of lying in court, damning report finds

image.altText: Man holding a child walks across building debris on flooded ground

items.synopsis: As people in coastal China flee successive typhoons and parts of the Philippines are awash, can decades-old experiments to control the weather offer a way forward? Or is there a risk some countries may use weather as a new kind of weapon?

title.children: In the future, we could snuff out cyclones — but does it risk weather being used as a weapon?

image.altText: Paul Virgona is dressed in a high-visibility orange vest as he smiles at the camera.

items.synopsis: Two Mongols bikies have been given jail sentences of at least three decades each for murdering fruiterer Paul Virgona in a case of mistaken identity.

title.children: Family grieve 'devoted father' as judge jails men who carried out mistaken-identity killing

image.altText: Rodriguez sits on the porch of a house

items.synopsis: Midnight Oil's former manager Zev Eizik booked the singer's first Australian tour in the 1970s. It didn't start off well.

title.children: Australia was early in embracing Rodriguez, a talent chewed up by the music industry

image.altText: A man is led away by corrections officers

items.synopsis: A 19-year-old charged over a crash that killed five teenagers south of Sydney last year pleads guilty in Picton Local Court.

title.children: Teen driver has bail revoked after pleading guilty to crash that killed five friends
